Princess Catalina embarks on an independent mission to find Lucia and invite her riding. After navigating the Alcázar corridors with Juan's help, she formally presents her petition to Lucia, who accepts with diplomatic ceremony. The encounter showcases Catalina's growing independence and the warm relationship developing between her and Lucia.

Juan takes Catalina and Lucia on a riding expedition to the countryside outside Toledo. Catalina shows remarkable courage and natural horsemanship during her first fast ride, delighting in the speed and competition. The outing strengthens the bond between Lucia and Catalina, with Lucia noting how the child has inherited Isabel's fearlessness and capacity for love. The event ends with intimate conversation about family and heritage.

Juan inspects the War Academy and discusses the planned Constantinople expedition with Sir Thomas Beaumont. They develop a strategy to involve academy cadets as observers rather than commanders, conduct pre-departure training for Order knights on Ottoman tactics, and establish a system for preserving battlefield knowledge through veteran instructors at the academy.

Juan instructs Álvaro to write to the military order masters, inviting them to Toledo for strategic discussions about the potential Constantinople deployment. The letters will frame this as consultation rather than command, mentioning new intelligence from Morocco and Constantinople. Álvaro suggests timing the meeting around Juan's wedding on December 3rd, and mentions that Fray Hernando has requested an audience about a spiritual matter.

Fray Hernando counsels Juan before his wedding to Lucia, expressing concerns about the speed of their courtship while affirming Juan's spiritual growth. They discuss Juan's grief over Isabel and the importance of sharing memories with his new bride. The session concludes with prayer for the upcoming Constantinople campaign, focusing on humility and divine guidance.

King Juan II marries Lucia of Ferrara in Toledo's cathedral before the assembled nobility of Castile. After exchanging vows blessed by Archbishop Alonso, they celebrate with a great feast where young Catalina expresses her approval of her new stepmother. The royal couple then retires to consummate their marriage.

On their wedding night, Juan and Lucia consummate their marriage and share intimate confessions. Juan reveals his divine sense of purpose and grand ambitions for a Christian empire, while Lucia transforms from a guarded political pawn into his strategic partner. They plan their joint rule, with Lucia attending all meetings and serving as regent when Juan campaigns. Their partnership deepens into a shared vision of conquest and reform.

Juan briefs Lucia on the complex Church politics involving Rome and Basel while they dress after their wedding night, then they share breakfast with Catalina. Lucia quickly grasps the delicate balance needed between papal and conciliar factions for the Constantinople expedition.

The royal family commissions three coordinated sets of formal wear from Master Gonzalo and Donna Francesca. During the fitting session, Catalina asks to call Lucia 'Lucia-mama,' leading to an emotional moment where the new family bonds are formally acknowledged through the child's innocent acceptance.

In a touching moment, Princess Catalina formally accepts Queen Lucia as 'Lucia-mama,' bringing tears to the chamber as Master Gonzalo speaks of dressing a family rather than just kings. The intimate family scene concludes as Juan and Lucia prepare to meet with the Masters of the Military Orders to discuss the campaigns to Constantinople and Morocco.

Juan convenes a council meeting with the Military Orders to discuss Constantinople and Morocco strategy. He introduces Queen Lucia as his future regent and grants all Granada fortresses to the three Orders. The discussion covers three strategic options for Constantinople: honor commitments and withdraw, evacuate willing Greeks, or fight under Castilian authority. The Orders express concerns about their future purpose post-Reconquista and the challenges of naval warfare, while reports reveal increasing Barbary corsair activity affecting merchant shipping.

Juan II assigns the three military orders their portions of conquered Granada, granting each order coastal fortresses and ports to develop naval capabilities against Barbary pirates. Santiago receives the central region including Granada itself, Calatrava takes the eastern region with Almería, and Alcántara gets the western region facing Morocco with Marbella. All orders are granted mooring rights at Málaga. The masters agree to work out detailed boundaries amongst themselves and present formal agreements for royal signature.

Juan takes Lucia and Catalina to the stables for the promised riding expedition. They visit Fernando in the nursery first, then head to the countryside where Juan and Catalina gallop on Hidalgo while Lucia gives chase on Tormenta. Catalina falls asleep in Lucia's arms on the ride home, demonstrating the deep trust and bond that has formed between stepmother and daughter in just a few weeks.

Juan prepares for a family retreat to Madrid with Lucia and Catalina. They decide to travel on horseback rather than by carriage, with Catalina riding alternately with her parents. Álvaro arranges a forty-man escort while the Italian ladies debate who will accompany the Queen. Fernando remains in Toledo under Beatriz's care.

The royal family's journey from Toledo to Madrid proceeds under ideal conditions—a bright, crisp December day with Princess Catalina proving an exemplary traveler, delighting in everything she sees and behaving perfectly throughout the ride.

The royal family enjoys a pleasant winter journey from Toledo to Madrid. Catalina proves an ideal traveling companion, delighting in everything she sees and behaving perfectly. The party arrives at the hunting lodge in good spirits with time to spare, finding warm fires and prepared rooms awaiting them.

Upon arriving at the Madrid hunting lodge, Juan and Lucia discuss travel arrangements for their upcoming journey to Valencia and Rome. They consider whether to travel simply like a family or with full royal ceremony, ultimately deciding to bring Catalina along with a carriage for her comfort and safety during the longer journey ahead.

Princess Catalina conducts a thorough inspection of the Madrid hunting lodge, evaluating its modest size, warm fireplace, and hunting tapestries before declaring it 'good' and demanding food with characteristic toddler directness.

The royal family enjoys an intimate dinner at the Madrid hunting lodge. Young Catalina delights in building bread towers and refusing vegetables, while Juan and Lucia savor the quiet domesticity. A conception roll determines that Lucia will become pregnant in January 1434, with the child due in October.

The royal family enjoys a peaceful winter retreat at the Madrid hunting lodge, away from court pressures. Lucia adapts well to the informal setting, teaching Catalina Italian, while Juan prepares his daughter for their upcoming Constantinople journey by ensuring she becomes comfortable with riding and outdoor activities.

King Alfonso V of Aragon travels personally from Sicily to Toledo to serve as godfather to Prince Fernando's baptism, demonstrating his commitment to the Castilian alliance. He brings news that Pope Eugenius has officially withdrawn recognition of René of Anjou's claim to Naples and delivers a letter from Byzantine Emperor John VIII Palaiologos with a proposal regarding Constantinople.

Emperor John VIII Palaiologos sends a desperate letter through Alfonso requesting true alliance with Castile. Constantinople is dying slowly—only 40,000 people remain, walls are crumbling, and the empire survives on Ottoman sufferance. Alfonso proposes naval power as the key to changing the strategic balance. Juan commits to visiting Constantinople personally to assess the situation.

Juan commits full support to Alfonso's Naples campaign, providing 40,000 florins, naval display of force at Valencia, and diplomatic pressure on Genoa and Milan. Alfonso explains his strategic needs and timeline, with both kings agreeing to coordinate the Naples campaign completion with Juan's planned Constantinople expedition in spring 1434.

Juan meets with Isabel's four Portuguese ladies-in-waiting to discuss their uncertain future. He offers them the choice to return to Portugal or remain at court, with Beatriz accepting to stay and care for the children. Juan privately grants each lady 40 florins toward their dowries to secure their futures.

Juan provides forty florins dowry to each of Queen Isabel's four Portuguese ladies-in-waiting, ensuring their marriage prospects in Castile. All four accept gratefully and choose to remain, with the funds held securely in the royal treasury. The gesture demonstrates royal honor and may benefit diplomatic relations with Portugal.

Don Íñigo López de Mendoza's delegation to Ferrara achieves exceptional success. Lucia d'Este not only accepts Juan's marriage proposal but is genuinely intrigued by his personal letter. She insists on meeting Juan privately before the formal betrothal, demonstrating her intelligence and independence. The match is agreed with favorable terms, and Lucia departs for Castile with the delegation, expected to arrive in Toledo by early November.

Prince Fernando's baptism ceremony takes place in Toledo Cathedral with great pageantry. Queen Leonor of Portugal and King Alfonso V of Aragon serve as godparents. Juan establishes a perpetual charitable endowment of 25,000 florins in Isabel's memory to provide dowries for poor maidens. The celebration continues with a feast at the Alcázar, where Juan shares an intimate moment with Catalina amid the grand festivities.

During Prince Fernando's baptism feast, Juan creates an intimate moment by dining with his young daughter Catalina in his lap, sharing food and tender exchanges while surrounded by the grand celebration. As the evening progresses and Catalina grows sleepy, Juan decides to introduce her to the noble guests before putting her to bed.

Breaking protocol, Juan carries his drowsy daughter Catalina through the feast hall to personally meet with noble families. He honors House Mendoza by addressing their needs and acknowledging their loyalty, then moves to House Manrique where he discusses the northern lords' restlessness after Granada's fall and hints at future military ventures. The intimate gesture of introducing Catalina strengthens bonds with key families while demonstrating Juan's unconventional approach to kingship.

Juan continues his rounds among the nobility with Catalina, moving from House Manrique to House Velasco. The interaction transforms when Catalina bonds with six-year-old María Velasco, a spirited girl with martial ambitions. The informal play between the children breaks down the formal barriers, warming the previously guarded Count of Haro toward Juan. Juan entrusts Catalina to the Velasco family's care while he continues greeting other nobles.

A roll to determine how the Castilian nobility reacts to Juan's unprecedented behavior at the baptism feast—leaving the high table to circulate among guests with Catalina, sitting with families as near-equals, and trusting the Velascos with his daughter. The result shows the night becomes legendary, transforming Juan's reputation and beginning to heal old wounds, particularly with the Velasco house.

Over ten days following the baptism feast, Juan settles into a domestic routine with his children—morning breakfasts with Catalina involving negotiations over food, quiet hours holding Fernando in the nursery. The Portuguese ladies find their footing in court, and Juan manages matters of state between family time. When word arrives that Lucia d'Este approaches Toledo, Juan makes careful preparations including commissioning an elegant sapphire ring and arranging for their first private meeting, choosing to present himself and his children to her rather than meeting alone.

Juan prepares for his first meeting with Lucia d'Este by setting up a private dinner in the solar with his children Catalina and Fernando present, along with their attendants. As evening falls, Lucia arrives at the prepared chamber where Juan waits with the engagement ring and an elegant but modest supper arrangement.

Juan meets Lucia d'Este for the first time in his solar, introducing her immediately to his children Catalina and Fernando. The roll determines Lucia's reaction to this approach - she shows cautious interest, appreciating his informality while maintaining careful reserve. She engages politely with the children but keeps Juan at a distance, testing whether his actions match the promises in his letter. The meeting begins with mutual assessment rather than immediate connection.

Juan and Lucia's first private meeting reveals deep compatibility as he explains his faith-driven kingship and she responds with unexpected emotional openness. Their conversation moves from political assessment to genuine connection, culminating in a moonlit garden walk where attraction and understanding flourish.

Juan's marriage proposal to Lucia d'Este reaches its climax in the moonlit garden. After an evening of deep conversation, Juan kneels before her with the specially designed ring, honestly describing the challenges of being queen while promising true partnership. A roll of 83 produces a transcendent moment—Lucia accepts with overwhelming emotion, declaring her willingness to be his partner in all things while warning she will never be a quiet wife. The evening ends with Juan carrying her back to their table, both laughing and crying, the ring fitting perfectly on her finger.

Juan reveals his deepest imperial ambitions to Lucia, sharing his plans to demand authority over Constantinople in exchange for military aid, ultimately seeking to unite Portugal, Castile, Navarre, Aragon, Naples, Sicily, and Greece under one crown. Lucia comprehends the vast scope of his vision and solemnly promises to keep this dangerous secret, understanding the trust he has placed in her.

Juan spends two weeks at the Madrid lodge training young Princess Catalina to ride in preparation for the Constantinople journey. Starting with short circuits, she gradually builds endurance to handle two-hour rides, learning proper grip and balance while Lucia provides encouragement and distraction during the longer sessions.

Juan returns to Toledo and meets with Álvaro to plan the Constantinople expedition. The fleet is nearly ready in Valencia, including the newly completed flagship Princess Catalina. Juan begins discussing which courtiers will accompany the royal family on the voyage.

Juan inquires about the status of the royal fleet for the Constantinople expedition. Álvaro reports that the flagship Princess Catalina is complete and ready, along with three new carracks and eight Genoese transport vessels. Juan clarifies he wants to use his commissioned flagship rather than a hired vessel, and begins discussing travel arrangements with Queen Lucia.

Juan and Lucia plan the selection of ladies-in-waiting for their voyage to Constantinople. They decide on three ladies: Donna Francesca and Donna Isabella from Lucia's Italian household, plus Doña Leonor de Almeida from the Portuguese ladies. Doña Beatriz will remain in Toledo with Prince Fernando. They also decide to bring one nursemaid for Princess Catalina.

Juan and Lucia meet with the four Portuguese ladies to discuss selecting one to accompany them to Constantinople. Beatriz will stay with Fernando. Leonor offers her close connection to Isabel and experience with Catalina, while Maria emphasizes her practical sailing experience. Inês expresses willingness despite her fears. The decision remains open as Lucia considers the options.

Juan finalizes the selection of travel companions for the Constantinople voyage. After deliberation with Lucia, he chooses Doña Leonor for her emotional connection to Queen Isabel, along with Lucia's Italian ladies and a nursemaid. Doña Maria gracefully accepts remaining behind, while Doña Inês is visibly relieved to avoid the journey.

Juan receives a comprehensive status report on the 700 knights from the Military Orders who will sail to Constantinople. All have been assembled in Toledo and trained at the War Academy in Ottoman tactics, though their experience is primarily against Granada rather than the Ottomans. The knights are ready to march to Valencia within a week, and Juan presses for the earliest possible departure date.

Juan II decides to accelerate his departure timeline, planning to visit Barcelona in mid-January before sailing to Constantinople. Despite Álvaro's concerns about winter travel conditions, the king chooses to frame the Barcelona visit as a family meeting with political undertones to strengthen Castilian-Aragonese relations and cultivate noble allies.

Juan decides to test the new royal carriage with a short family journey to Aranjuez. The three-day trip will include Catalina, Lucia, and the court ladies to evaluate their traveling capabilities before the planned Barcelona visit. Álvaro arranges for the carriage to be completed within five days with appropriate provisions and escort.

Juan explains the travel plans to his family in the nursery—first a test journey to Aranjuez, then a larger expedition to Barcelona and Valencia. Catalina shows cautious interest in the carriage concept but wants to see it first. Lucia notes the challenges of the winter journey through Aragón with a young child.

Juan inspects the newly completed carriage with Lucia and Catalina. The toddler delights in exploring the interior, declaring it 'good' and 'cosy.' After settling Lucia and Catalina inside with blankets, Juan mounts Hidalgo to begin testing the carriage with a short ride, with Catalina excitedly watching the movement through the window.

During a test journey with the new carriage, young Catalina becomes nauseous from bouncing enthusiastically on the cushions. She transfers to ride with Juan on Hidalgo, recovering quickly in the fresh air. When asked to choose between horse and carriage, she diplomatically declares the horse better for seeing and speed, while the carriage is good for sleeping.

Juan spends final weeks retraining in armor to prepare for the voyage, gradually recovering his warrior reflexes. On the cold morning of departure, he visits the nursery to bid farewell to his infant son Fernando, entrusting the child to Doña Beatriz's care.

On the morning of departure for Constantinople, Juan visits the nursery to bid farewell to his four-month-old son Fernando. Doña Beatriz promises to care for the prince and tell him stories of his father. The tender moment captures the weight of leaving his infant son for months while sailing to defend Christendom.

Juan II makes final farewells in Toledo before departing for Constantinople. After emotional goodbyes with infant Fernando and Álvaro de Luna, he mounts Hidalgo with young Catalina and leads the expedition column out of the city gates, beginning the long journey to Barcelona and ultimately to defend Constantinople against Ottoman forces.

The royal journey from Toledo to Barcelona proceeds exceptionally well with favorable weather and enthusiastic reception from Aragonese towns celebrating the Reconquista. The remarkable event occurs in Fraga when twenty-month-old Princess Catalina wanders away from her nursemaid and saves a drowning boy by throwing him a rope and holding it until help arrives. The miracle becomes legendary, leading to the construction of a shrine and annual commemorations.

During a rest day in Fraga, twenty-month-old Princess Catalina wanders from the inn and performs a miraculous rescue at the old Roman bridge. When a four-year-old boy falls into the fast-flowing Cinca River, Catalina throws him a rope and holds it while men pull him to safety. The townspeople hail it as a miracle, and the story spreads throughout Aragon. A shrine will be built to commemorate the event.

The royal family arrives in Barcelona to a ceremonial welcome. Catalina sees the sea for the first time, and Juan is emotionally reunited with his sister Queen María, regent of Aragon, whom he has not seen in nearly four years.

Juan reunites with his sister María, regent of Aragon, after four years apart. She warmly welcomes Queen Lucia and is immediately charmed by Princess Catalina, who imperiously demands to be carried. The emotional reunion strengthens family bonds as María prepares to host them at the royal palace while hinting at complex political matters regarding Alfonso in Naples.

María privately informs Juan of Alfonso's breakthrough in the Naples campaign. Louis of Anjou is dying, Alfonso has landed at Reggio, major barons are switching sides, and the papal endorsement has isolated the Angevins diplomatically. Alfonso's approach has become more strategic and patient following his earlier defeats.

Juan receives a respectful but measured welcome at the Aragonese court in Barcelona. The nobles acknowledge his Reconquista achievements while carefully emphasizing shared Iberian heritage rather than Castilian dominance. Catalina charms the court, and Don Ramon de Perellós, María's chief councilor, requests to speak privately with Juan about the political situation.

At the Barcelona court, Juan is approached by two rival faction leaders after his speech. The Count of Pallars challenges him about Aragon's costly Italian wars, while Don Guillem de Vic promotes continued support for Alfonso's Naples campaign. Juan diplomatically acknowledges the war's costs while showing Alfonso's encouraging letter and promising personal support, earning cautious respect from the skeptical Count.

Juan negotiates with Count Pallars and Don Guillem de Vic in Barcelona. Pallars remains cautiously skeptical about Castilian involvement in Naples despite Alfonso's letter showing progress. Don Guillem eagerly offers to broker additional Castilian aid to Alfonso, securing a promise of royal debt. When Juan proposes broader trade cooperation involving Granada's new resources, Guillem deflects to post-war discussions while protecting Catalan commercial interests.

Juan presses Don Guillem beyond diplomatic platitudes to genuine commitment. After initial deflection, Guillem's courtier mask slips as Juan asks for truth and admits his own uncertainty. The conversation becomes unexpectedly intimate as both men reveal vulnerability — Juan his doubts about uniting the kingdoms, Guillem his inexperience with idealism beyond profit. Juan frames unity as a shared effort using each person's unique skills, asking simply if Guillem will try alongside him.

After Guillem de Vic makes a private commitment to help unite Castile and Aragon through his merchant connections, Juan makes a public announcement to the entire Aragonese court declaring Guillem's commitment. The court responds with genuine enthusiasm, with María publicly endorsing the vision and even Count Pallars showing cautious support. The factional divisions begin to blur as nobles rally around the idea of the kingdoms as family.

The evening reception starts well but deteriorates as fatigue sets in. Catalina has a public tantrum and must be taken to bed, removing Juan's most effective ambassador. The royal couple grows tired, conversations become repetitive, and the magic of the earlier announcement begins to fade. Juan wisely chooses to retire before further damage is done, though the transformative moment has already diminished into mere diplomacy.

In their private chambers, Lucia expresses both wonder and fear at Juan's divine certainty after witnessing his speech to Don Guillem. She asks him to speak with his confessor about presumption and the limits of mortal strength, but Juan responds with theological explanations rather than the simple promise she seeks. The conversation ends with Lucia withdrawing emotionally, accepting his kiss but turning away in disappointment, leaving Juan with silence and a subtle shift in their relationship.

During a morning conversation in their bedchamber, Lucia confronts Juan about their argument from the previous night. She articulates her fear that Juan's certainty about his divine purpose could be dangerous presumption, asking him to genuinely examine his conscience with Fray Hernando rather than seeking reassurance. Juan offers to include Lucia in a three-way conversation with his confessor, and they reach a tentative reconciliation, though underlying tensions remain about Juan's spiritual certainty and risk-taking.

In a private meeting with María of Aragon, Juan reveals his true plan: he wants Alfonso to name him heir, effectively uniting Castile and Aragon under one crown to face threats like the Ottomans. María responds with cold calculation, immediately grasping the personal and political implications of what Juan is asking her to facilitate.

María rejects Juan's succession proposal, hurt that he presented his plan only after publicly positioning himself. She acknowledges his clarifications but feels treated as an audience rather than family. Though not saying no definitively, she needs time to consult Alfonso directly and cannot commit to supporting the union under these circumstances.

Juan and Lucia meet with Bishop Francesc Climent Sapera of Barcelona in the Palau Reial. The bishop initially probes diplomatically about Juan's 'unity' speech, but Juan's respectful approach encourages frank discussion. The bishop reveals three major Aragonese Church concerns: fears about royal control over institutions following the Military Orders precedent, worries about Castilian influence over traditional Aragonese episcopal appointments, and anxiety among clergy who supported the Council of Basel. Juan begins addressing these concerns, starting with reassurances about the Military Orders being a unique situation born of mutual benefit rather than a template for broader church control.

Juan addresses the Bishop's concerns about military orders, episcopal elections, and church reform by revealing his complete diplomatic position. He shows all documents including the Declaration of Como with Emperor Sigismund, correspondence with Pope Eugenius, and Basel delegation instructions. When asked what he wants from Barcelona's Church, Juan gives a deeply spiritual answer about doing good works and walking in God's glory. The Bishop's cynical expectations are completely overturned by Juan's transparency and genuine faith.

When Juan reveals he wants nothing from Barcelona's Church except for it to fulfill its spiritual mission, the Bishop experiences a spiritual awakening. The old priest remembers why he entered the Church forty years ago, admits he had forgotten the Church's true purpose amid decades of politics, and offers genuine partnership. He promises to write supportive letters to other Aragonese bishops, support the Constantinople expedition as a crusade, and provide blessed alliance when Juan returns. The meeting ends with Juan kneeling to receive the Bishop's genuine blessing and requesting to pray together or attend mass.

Juan receives a deeply personal blessing from the Bishop of Barcelona, who confesses his spiritual crisis and admits he no longer feels the faith he once had as a young priest. Juan's request to see 'the priest who believed' moves the bishop to vulnerability and self-reflection. The bishop invites them to Mass the next morning, promising to try to rediscover his lost faith.

Juan and Lucia visit the nursery where Catalina has been playing with young Lord Bernat. They discover she has been dominating their games and eating more than her share of treats. Juan teaches her about sharing equally and letting others tell her stories, while Lucia suggests they play with reversed roles. Catalina reluctantly agrees to let Bernat be king while she is a viscountess, but negotiates to remain 'very important' and retain ownership of the toy horse.

After his meeting with Bishop Climent, Juan decides to meet with Don Ramon de Perellós at the Palau Reial to discuss court administration and the itinerary for his remaining time in Barcelona, with other important meetings scheduled for the day.

Juan meets with Don Ramon de Perellós, who confronts him about bypassing the regency council in his private meetings with various factions. Juan apologizes and reveals his vision for uniting the kingdoms as equals, not through Castilian dominance. Don Ramon responds cautiously, revealing that Juan is actually Alfonso's heir presumptive to the Crown of Aragón, which explains why his unity discussions alarm everyone. The regent insists future succession talks must include the full council.

Juan meets with Barcelona's Consell de Cent to discuss trade concerns regarding Granada's conquered ports. The Catalans, led by Pere Joan de Sant Climent and Bernat Fiveller, press for concrete assurances that Catalan merchants will receive equal treatment in Castilian-controlled Granada. After initial evasions about international conferences, Juan finally agrees to draft a simple letter instructing his port officials to treat Aragonese merchants as equals to Castilians.

Juan unexpectedly agrees to draft a comprehensive trade letter during the Barcelona council meeting. The letter establishes equal treatment for merchants across kingdoms, anti-piracy cooperation, Granada silk trade regulation, and merchant notification policies. Barcelona reciprocates with matching commitments for Castilian traders and pledges to host future trade conferences.

In private chambers, Count Pallars confronts Juan about his true intentions regarding Aragonese succession and the costly Italian wars. After Juan admits his succession ambitions while promising to counsel Alfonso to end the Naples campaign, Pallars remains cautiously skeptical about whether Juan sees Aragón as partners or as resources to exploit.

Juan promises to counsel Alfonso to end the Neapolitan war when he visits in March, but insists he can only speak for Castile and would need regency council blessing to represent Aragonese interests. Count Pallars, disappointed by Juan's cautious approach and offers to merely carry messages rather than use his influence decisively, departs with cold courtesy, viewing Juan as a king of careful words but little action.

María de Castilla agrees to summon the regency council with strict conditions: she will control the agenda and proceedings, succession topics are off-limits until Alfonso is consulted, and Juan may attend only as an honored guest with voice but no authority. The meeting is set for February 6th, with Juan accepting all terms.

Juan attends Mass at Barcelona's cathedral and requests prayers for the fallen sons of Aragón and their families. Bishop Climent Sapera delivers a powerful homily about service over glory and prays for the war dead by name, causing profound emotional release among the congregation. The event unexpectedly draws political figures and reveals Queen María's grief.

Over nine days, Juan immerses himself in Barcelona's cultural life with Catalina and Lucia. They attend the Festa de Sant Pau, visit the royal shipyards, explore the merchant exchange, practice with crossbowmen, hunt with Aragonese nobles, and wander the Boqueria market. The public activities gradually warm Barcelona's reception of the Castilian king, while private encounters begin to thaw relations with key figures like the Count of Pallars, setting the stage for the crucial regency council meeting.

A letter arrives from King Alfonso addressed to Queen María. She reads it privately and afterward sends word through Don Ramon that Juan's presence at the upcoming council meeting is welcome—a subtle but significant softening of her stance.

At the Regency Council meeting, Juan faces a hostile challenge from Viscount Rocabertí about signing trade agreements without permission. Juan's direct, transparent response acknowledging the facts while defending his sovereign rights impresses the council. María sharply rebukes Rocabertí for questioning Juan's sovereignty, dramatically shifting the room's dynamics in Juan's favor.

Juan addresses the Aragonese council about Constantinople, outlining three conditional options rather than crusading rhetoric. He offers to evacuate Greeks, repair walls, or fight only if other kingdoms commit. Despite his pragmatic approach, councillors press him on practical concerns about Aragonese merchant safety and coordination in Ottoman waters.

Juan negotiates the Constantinople issue by proposing mutual protection of subjects, but when offered advantage through unilateral commitment, he chooses to wait and negotiate directly with Alfonso as equals. The council is surprised by his honorable approach, earning their respect and defusing potential conflict over reciprocal obligations.

Count Pallars presents a draft letter to King Alfonso questioning the Naples war's costs after twelve years. Despite debate, the council votes 4-1 to send it via royal courier. Juan offers to personally assess the situation when meeting Alfonso, leading to the compromise that the letter travels separately from Juan's diplomatic mission.

In a private garden conversation, María opens up to Juan about her deep uncertainty about her own desires and identity after years of living only to fulfill others' expectations. She reveals her fears about becoming irrelevant and her struggle with never having been asked what she wants for herself. Through tears and vulnerability, they reach a breakthrough when Juan's simple invitation to visit with pastries breaks through her walls, leading to genuine laughter and her agreement to try discovering her own wants while building a relationship as his sister.

A survival roll determined that Princess Catalina will survive the dangerous years of medieval childhood. Despite high infant mortality rates of the era, she will live to grow up, experiencing only minor illnesses and accidents. Additional trait rolls revealed her as brilliant (87), commanding (76), musically gifted with an angelic voice (5), indifferent to faith (7), and beautiful (70). The cruel irony emerges that her divine singing voice moves others to tears during sacred music, yet she feels no spiritual connection herself.

María visits the royal family in their private apartments, sharing ensaïmadas with young Catalina. The informal setting allows María to drop her regent's formality and reconnect with her family, particularly bonding with her energetic niece. The visit culminates in plans to go horseback riding together to watch the ships in Barcelona's harbor, marking a significant softening in family relationships.

A family horseback ride to Montjuïc Hill becomes a healing moment for María of Aragón. Through Catalina's innocent offer of care and a shared crostata in María's chambers, the lonely regent experiences genuine familial connection for the first time in years, finding comfort in the simple act of being part of a loving family.

Juan inspects his assembled knights preparing for the Constantinople expedition but discovers a crisis: fever has sickened sixty men with three deaths, spoiled supplies from Valencia have created shortages, and morale is collapsing among the veteran Granada campaigners who see only delay and confusion. The Order commanders blame each other while six hundred and forty healthy men await leadership to restore their faith in the mission.

Juan addresses his assembled knights in full armor beneath the white crusade banner, acknowledging their hardships while calling upon memories of Granada's victory and their destiny as the only hope for Constantinople. The knights respond to the traditional prayer but with tired voices and lingering doubt. Captain Robles warns that the speech has bought only time—practical problems must be solved quickly or the words will turn to resentment.

Juan convenes an urgent meeting with his military commanders to address critical expedition problems: sick men in inadequate tents, spoiled supplies, and command structure disputes. He secures hospital care for the ill, orders supply missions to procure 250-300 barrels of meat, and gives the three Order commanders one day to choose unified leadership or face his direct appointment. The meeting transforms from finger-pointing to problem-solving.

Juan resolves the camp crisis through systematic action: moving the sick to Barcelona's hospital, securing María's support for a feast, personally inspecting and improving camp conditions, and ensuring fresh water supply. The men's morale is restored through the feast provided by María, and the camp becomes functional again, though command structure issues remain unresolved.

The three military order commanders present their negotiated proposal for unified command structure. Commander Mendoza of Calatrava will lead overall forces, with Sergeant Palencia of Alcántara as quartermaster and Commander Cervantes as second. Juan accepts their decision and sets March 5th as the departure date, pending final supply deliveries and equipment inspections.

Juan brings his family to inspect the flagship Princesa Catalina. The young princess Catalina is delighted to discover the ship bears her name and declares it hers. Captain Sotomayor gives them a comprehensive tour of the carrack, showing the royal chambers originally designed for Queen Isabel, the gun deck with twelve bombards, and the crew quarters. The ship is revealed to be well-prepared for the upcoming journey to Constantinople, capable of carrying eighty souls and provisioned for three months at sea.

Juan meets with Don Ramon de Perellós, head of the regency council, who questions his private meetings with various factions. Juan makes full disclosure of his unity vision and succession concerns. Don Ramon reveals that Juan is legally Alfonso's heir presumptive to Aragón, explaining why his talk of 'bringing kingdoms together' alarms everyone. He insists future discussions involve the full council.

Juan requests a full regency council meeting to address succession matters that are already on everyone's minds. Don Ramón carefully explains the logistical requirements and political protocols needed for such a meeting, emphasizing that Queen María must consent and preside. Juan agrees to defer all succession discussions to the council's authority.

Juan meets with Barcelona's Consell de Cent to discuss trade relations. The councillors, led by Pere Joan de Sant Climent and merchant representative Bernat Fiveller, press him about preferential treatment for Catalan merchants in Granada's newly conquered ports. They acknowledge Juan's likely future as King of Aragón and seek concrete assurances about equal treatment. Juan offers philosophical support for fair trade but avoids specific commitments, ultimately agreeing that equal treatment would align with his stated goals.

Juan II concludes trade negotiations with Barcelona's Consell de Cent by drafting a comprehensive royal letter addressing Catalan concerns about equal treatment in Castilian ports, anti-piracy cooperation, Granada silk regulation, and information sharing. The council reciprocates by committing Barcelona to equal treatment of Castilian merchants and agreeing to host an international traders' conference.

Count Pallars confronts Juan about his true intentions in Aragón, expressing fear that Juan sees the realm as a source of men and money for future wars. Juan admits the succession question openly and promises to counsel Alfonso to end the Italian war when he visits him en route to Constantinople. The conversation reveals the deep tensions between Aragonese war-weariness and Juan's previous financial support for Alfonso's campaign.

Juan offers to counsel Alfonso to end the war and carry messages from the Aragonese faction, but insists on proper authorization from the regency council. Pallars, disappointed by Juan's cautious approach and reluctance to use his influence directly, leaves believing Juan means well but doubts his effectiveness in stopping the Italian war that has claimed so many Aragonese lives.

Juan requests Bishop Climent Sapera pray for the fallen sons of Aragón during Mass at Barcelona Cathedral. The bishop's powerful sermon and prayer for the war dead moves the congregation to tears, creating a moment of profound grief and healing. Juan's young daughter Catalina learns about death and compassion, ultimately deciding to offer comfort to grieving strangers with her parents' support.

Juan attempts to comfort a grieving widow by having Catalina approach her, but the toddler becomes frightened and hides against her father's leg. The encounter becomes awkward, though Juan manages to salvage it somewhat by speaking gently with the widow about her losses and offering prayers. The widow reveals she lost both husband and son in the war, and expresses gratitude that their names were finally spoken in church.

Juan meets with Don Guillem de Vic to review trade correspondence, including letters to the Gualbes banking family and frameworks for Castilian-Catalan merchant cooperation. The conversation reveals Don Guillem's internal conflict between supporting the war effort and acknowledging its human costs, particularly after Juan's prayer for fallen soldiers. Juan approves the well-crafted letters and plans to spend coming days experiencing Catalan culture.
events.location: Barcelona, Don Guillem de Vic's Residence

events.summary: Over nine days in Barcelona, Juan participates in the Festa de Sant Pau, visits shipyards and markets, hunts with Aragonese nobles, and builds relationships with local merchants and craftsmen. Catalina charms the citizens while the Count of Pallars begins to warm to Juan. María receives a letter from Alfonso and declares Juan's presence at the upcoming council 'welcome.'

Juan faces the Aragonese Regency Council as an honored guest with limited authority. When Viscount Rocabertí challenges his right to write trade instructions to his own officials, Juan defends himself directly, prompting María to intervene decisively against the Viscount for questioning royal sovereignty. The council accepts trade agreements in principle and begins discussing Juan's Constantinople expedition.

Juan presents his three-option approach to Constantinople to the Aragonese council, emphasizing caution over crusading glory. When pressed on protecting Aragonese interests, he offers written commitments but suggests mutual obligations. Rather than forcing Aragón into an awkward position, he voluntarily proposes to negotiate directly with Alfonso as equals, earning unexpected respect from the council.

The Aragonese council debates a letter to King Alfonso urging him to reconsider the costly Naples campaign. Juan offers to personally assess the situation and counsel Alfonso if needed, but predicts the letter will achieve nothing. The council votes 4-1 to send the letter by royal courier rather than having Juan carry it. Pallars concludes by formally commending Juan's honorable conduct during the proceedings.

Juan and María share a private conversation in the regent's garden. María confronts Juan about her future role as his power grows, expressing fear of being marginalized despite her years of governing Aragón. When Juan offers various possibilities for her future, she rejects them as condescending charity, revealing her deep struggle with never having been asked what she truly wants for herself.

In an emotional breakthrough, María finally opens up about her lifelong struggle with never being allowed to want anything for herself, from childhood dreams to her desperate desire for a child. When Juan offers simple family connection through a visit with pastries, she breaks down in tears of recognition and agrees to come meet his family as a sister rather than a queen.

A critical survival roll determines that Princess Catalina will survive the dangerous years of medieval childhood. Despite the high mortality rates of the 15th century, she will grow up healthy, living through occasional fevers and childhood ailments but ultimately reaching adulthood intact.

Character generation rolls for Princess Catalina reveal her future traits: exceptional intelligence and natural command presence, beautiful appearance, and a divine singing voice. However, she will lack genuine religious faith despite her musical gifts making her the finest sacred performer in Castile - creating a painful irony for her deeply devout father Juan II.

María visits Juan's family in their private apartments, sharing ensaïmadas with young Catalina. Through the child's innocent enthusiasm, María begins to soften from her formal regent role, rediscovering simple pleasures like family time and the prospect of riding horses for enjoyment rather than duty. The intimate breakfast leads to plans for a family outing to watch ships from Montjuïc hill.

During a family outing to view ships from Montjuïc, young Catalina's innocent questions about who cares for María touch the lonely Regent deeply. The child's offer of comfort through 'crostatas and hugs' breaks María's emotional barriers. They share a simple pastry together in María's private chambers, where she finds unexpected healing through Catalina's pure affection and the warmth of family connection.

Juan inspects his 700 knights assembled for the Constantinople crusade but finds the camp in crisis—fever has struck sixty men, supplies have spoiled, and morale is broken. Despite donning his Granada armor and delivering an inspiring speech invoking their past victories, the men's response is lukewarm. The speech steadies them temporarily but does not restore their faith, leaving Juan with only days to solve the practical problems before losing them entirely.

Juan meets with his military commanders to address the expedition's crisis. After breaking up their feuding, he secures hospital care for sick men, arranges expanded food supplies through multiple Mediterranean ports, and forces the three Order commanders to choose unified leadership or have it imposed upon them by tomorrow.

Juan personally oversees comprehensive improvements to the crusader camp. The Hospital de la Santa Creu accepts all sixty sick knights, María arranges a generous feast from palace stores, fresh water barrels arrive, and latrines are properly relocated. The camp transforms from a place of despair into one of renewed hope and purpose.

After the day's crisis, Juan visits his daughter Catalina in the nursery. She asks him to sing a lullaby, and he does so until she falls asleep. Queen Lucia appears silently in the doorway, sharing this quiet family moment after the troubles of the day.

The three military order commanders present a unified proposal for command structure after private negotiations. Mendoza of Calatrava becomes overall commander, Palencia of Alcántara becomes quartermaster, and Cervantes of Santiago accepts second-in-command. Juan accepts their proposal, sets March 5th as the departure date, and commits to regular presence at camp as the campaign officially begins.

Juan takes Lucia and Catalina to inspect the flagship Princesa Catalina in Barcelona harbor. The young princess is delighted that the great carrack bears her name, while Captain Sotomayor gives them a comprehensive tour of the vessel's royal cabins, gun deck, holds, and fighting platforms. The ship is well-built and ready for the coming voyage to Constantinople, though the queen's cabin—originally designed for Isabel—carries poignant reminders of the past.

Juan II arrives in Rome by river barge with his family and household after anchoring at Ostia. The journey follows a devastating storm that cost 75 lives, but the royal party reaches the eternal city safely with 591 surviving knights to follow overland.

As Juan approaches Rome, he reviews months of correspondence from his delegation at Basel. The Council has passed major reforms on clerical concubinage, pluralism, and annates, negotiated peace with the Hussites through the Compacts of Basel, and proclaimed a crusade for Constantinople. Though successful, the crusade decree provides more legitimacy than actual military support, leaving Juan to carry the burden himself.

As the royal barge approaches Rome, Fray Hernando explains the doctrine of concomitance that resolved the Bohemian communion dispute, details how the Basel reform decrees close the dispensation loopholes that undermined previous reforms, and reveals why the Council cannot conclude—the fundamental conflict between papal and conciliar supremacy remains unresolved, with the French faction preparing for a final constitutional battle that could shatter all the progress made.

Fray Hernando explains the constitutional mechanisms by which the Council of Basel might end, revealing there is no clear path to dissolution. He outlines three theoretical possibilities—papal dissolution, conciliar self-dissolution, or mutual agreement—but demonstrates why none are viable in practice. The discussion clarifies how the parallel legislation Juan carries could route around the constitutional conflict by achieving reform through papal authority alone.

As the royal barge docks in Rome, Fray Hernando provides Juan with a detailed historical explanation of the Council Frequens requirements and the failures of past councils, from Pavia-Siena's poor attendance to Basel's current conflict with the Pope, ending with Juan's inquiry about French factional influence.

Fray Hernando provides a detailed analysis of the French faction's strength at Basel, explaining how the Council's unique voting structure allows Cardinal d'Allemand to obstruct decisions without commanding a majority. He warns that time favors the French radicals as moderate delegates leave, making immediate papal action on reforms crucial.

In a Roman archway, Fray Hernando analyzes Juan's proposal to flood Basel with Italian clergy to end the Council. He identifies four major obstacles: administrative manipulation, perception of papal coercion, potential French walkout, and papal reluctance to validate conciliar authority. He proposes instead a gradual strategy where Eugenius voluntarily adopts reforms and slowly increases Italian attendance, allowing the Council to end through exhaustion rather than dramatic confrontation.

Fray Hernando explains to Juan II the paradox at the heart of conciliarism: the distinction between procedural and actual legitimacy. He argues that Basel's French faction exploits voting mechanisms while undermining their moral authority, and that Pope Eugenius makes the same error in reverse by simply denying the Council's authority. The friar proposes that the only path to avoid schism is mutual compromise where both sides yield something - the Pope accepting reform while the Council abandons claims of supremacy over papal authority.

Fray Hernando explains the financial mechanisms of the annates decree reform as the royal party walks through Rome. He details how the decree would split annates revenue between the papal treasury (Camera Apostolica) and metropolitan archbishops, severely reducing papal income while empowering provincial church authority. This represents a fundamental shift from centralized Roman control to decentralized provincial governance. Juan seeks advice on how to gauge papal sentiment before his official meeting.

Juan strategizes intelligence gathering before his papal audience, tasking Lucia to investigate Camera finances through Medici connections and approach Cardinal Capranica, while Fray Hernando will sound out Cardinal Orsini on papal receptiveness to reform. They plan to argue that proper annates collection under the reforms might actually increase papal revenues despite the reduced rates.

Lucia's attempt to gather information about papal financial collection rates through the Medici agent results in a carefully orchestrated evasion. A junior Camera clerk answers all her questions while revealing nothing substantive, confirming Lucia's suspicion that the Vatican finances are troubled but closely guarded.

Fray Hernando's diplomatic approach to Cardinal Orsini fails completely. The Cardinal, who had previously trusted Hernando with private counsel, now treats him with distant formality in a public room with secretaries present. Hernando learns nothing of Pope Eugenius's position on parallel legislation or the Basel proposals, leading Juan to decide on a more direct approach.

After learning that Cardinal Orsini has become distant and uncooperative, Juan decides to march all six hundred knights to Mass in Rome as a public demonstration. Despite Fray Hernando's careful counsel about the risks of such a dramatic gesture, Juan insists this is divine inspiration rather than pride, ordering the men assembled for Mass the following day.

Juan confesses to Fray Hernando about the seventy-five men lost in the storm, accepting responsibility for inadequate preparation. The conversation turns to Juan's struggle with pride versus divine purpose in his planned march through Rome tomorrow. Hernando absolves Juan for the fleet's losses but challenges him to discern whether his actions stem from pride or grace, refusing to provide easy answers and promising to watch Juan's march with keen spiritual scrutiny.

In an intimate evening conversation, Juan shares his theological reflections on pride versus grace with Lucia, who challenges him for treating her as a philosophical example rather than his wife. Their discussion reveals tensions between his grand rhetoric and personal relationships, ending with Lucia's practical support despite her concerns about his approach to the upcoming papal audience.

In the pre-dawn hours, Juan rises to prepare for a significant papal mass. He visits sleeping Catalina, then dons his armor while leaving his helmet behind to appear as a king attending mass rather than a warrior. After tender farewells with Lucia, who will watch from Castel Sant'Angelo, he departs to join his knights for their march to St. Peter's.

Juan leads his 591 crusaders in a ceremonial march through Rome to St. Peter's Basilica. The disciplined column moves silently through the city streets, drawing crowds and attention, before arriving at the Vatican where they are formally welcomed by the cathedral chapter for Mass.

Juan attends Mass at St. Peter's Basilica with 591 knights and his daughter Catalina. The Vatican sends no high officials, but Canon Giuliano Della Rovere agrees to include prayers for Juan's 75 fallen knights during the service. Papal secretaries observe and record the proceedings.

During Mass at St. Peter's, a mysterious Dominican friar approaches Fray Hernando with a cryptic message. The friar, representing unknown parties, requests a private meeting away from Vatican eyes and identifies himself through Brother Tomás de Torquemada at Santa Maria sopra Minerva. Juan agrees to arrange the meeting after addressing his knights.

Juan addresses his assembled troops in St. Peter's Paradiso, speaking of their mission to Constantinople and their upcoming departure for Naples. The speech takes place before a growing crowd of Romans and under the watchful eyes of the Vatican.

After Juan's speech to his knights in St. Peter's Paradiso, the Roman crowd lingers and discusses his words favorably, particularly praising his focus on faith over politics. The Vatican remains silent with no official response, but the common people show curiosity and interest in the Spanish king who spoke of wonder and beautiful moments.

Catalina enthusiastically waves at the Apostolic Palace from Juan's shoulder, calling out to the Pope. After a moment, someone in a third-floor window waves back, delighting both the child and the watching Romans in the piazza.

Brother Tomás de Torquemada, a Dominican serving the Aragonese Inquisition, meets with Juan II to probe his religious policies in Granada. Through careful questioning about converted Muslims like Commander Martín de Alcalá, Torquemada reveals his skepticism about the sincerity of mass conversions and advocates for systematic pressure to ensure religious conformity. Juan admits his pragmatic approach and reveals his plans to destroy all mosques and gradually expel Muslims from Granada.

Brother Torquemada presents a systematic plan for establishing the Inquisition in Granada, detailing methods of surveillance, investigation, and punishment for Muslim converts suspected of secret apostasy. He warns Juan of French intelligence networks in Rome and positions himself as a valuable contact for implementing inquisitorial authority in newly conquered territories.

Walking back from meeting Torquemada, Fray Hernando cautiously questions Juan's promise to install the Inquisition in Granada. Through careful dialogue, the Franciscan friar warns against hasty commitments and suggests examining the institution thoroughly, advocating for gentler approaches to salvation. Their relationship deepens as Juan reassures him of his good intentions and values his counsel.

Juan returns to Lucia and recounts his eventful day in Rome, including his encounter with Brother Tomás de Torquemada and his agreement to install an Inquisition in Granada. Lucia displays her Florentine political instincts, warning Juan that the Dominican may be manipulating him and questioning what the friar truly wants in return for his counsel.

Juan ventures alone into Rome's markets to buy oranges for Lucia, enjoying the anonymity of walking without guards or royal trappings. He purchases blood oranges from an old Sicilian woman and returns to find Lucia resting. They share the oranges together in a tender domestic moment, with Lucia skillfully peeling the fruit while they enjoy a rare hour of peaceful intimacy before their daughter wakes.

Juan and Lucia discuss their limited intelligence before the papal audience in three days. They decide to use the Medici banking connections to gather information about Vatican personnel and follow up on Cardinal Capranica's signal from Mass, seeking contacts who might provide insight into Pope Eugenius's intentions regarding the crusade and parallel legislation proposals.

Lucia's intelligence gathering through the Medici agent reveals crucial context about Pope Eugenius: the papal treasury is severely depleted, French cardinals are reporting to Basel and characterizing Juan's arrival as military pressure, and the Pope is cautious but hasn't rejected the parallel legislation proposal. Despite Juan's desire for more Vatican contacts, Lucia counsels patience, arguing that the consistent message to wait indicates the Pope himself will determine all outcomes at the upcoming audience.

After Lucia's counsel about approaching the Pope with truth rather than schemes, Juan abruptly decides to ride to Ostia to inspect his fleet. He arrives at night with twelve guards and announces plans for naval exercises from the Princess Catalina, asking Captain Morales about summoning the other ship captains.

Juan rides to Ostia Harbor at night to meet with his fleet captains aboard the Princess Catalina. He announces plans for naval exercises the following day to prepare for future storms, and informs them of the upcoming papal audience and departure to Naples.

Juan convenes his ten remaining ship captains to analyze the recent Mistral storm and develop better preparation protocols. The captains reveal that flag signals failed during the storm and ships with earlier warning suffered fewer casualties. They agree to implement dedicated weather watches, cannon warning signals, and pre-voyage planning councils to coordinate storm responses.

Juan holds a fleet council to establish storm warning procedures. The captains report their cannon capabilities, revealing four transport ships lack any artillery. They develop a system using the carracks as lookouts positioned at formation edges, with three cannon shots as the storm signal. Emergency procedures are established: all hands on deck, shorten sail, secure cargo, rig lifelines, man pumps, and follow predetermined bearings. Juan orders storm drills for the following day and considers adapting the system for enemy fleet encounters.

Juan finalizes storm drill procedures with his captains, establishing cannon signals and response protocols. Nine ships will participate in tomorrow's exercise while the Buenaventura stays in port for repairs. The captains express renewed confidence in their king's leadership after recent setbacks.

After dismissing his captains, Juan retires to his chambers aboard the Princess Catalina for his first night sleeping on his flagship. At dawn, he prepares for naval exercises with his fleet, asking about the number of participants as the ships ready themselves across the harbor.

Before the fleet exercise, Juan visits Ostia harbor at dawn to purchase provisions. He arranges to buy ten casks of drink from Maria at La Sirena tavern for pickup after the fleet returns, and receives directions to find Giacomo for better wine.

Juan purchases a barrel of quality Umbrian red wine from Giacomo, a merchant in Ostia Harbor, for eight florins. The transaction is for victory celebrations with the Castilian fleet, with pickup arranged for later that afternoon.

Juan II inspects the San Marcos and meets Pascual, the experienced lookout who spotted the approaching Mistral storm. He examines the ship's cannons and crew, learning about their storm-warning methods and gun procedures from Captain Diego Fernández and his gunners.

Juan assigns the crucial role of initiating the storm exercise to Pascual, the experienced lookout on the San Marcos. Pascual will shout the mistral warning one hour past zenith, prompting the cannon signals that will test the fleet's reaction time. The weathered sailor takes quiet pride in being trusted with this responsibility.

The fleet's first storm drill exercise reveals serious coordination problems. While the carracks perform adequately, the transports struggle with confused signals, hungover crews, and equipment failures. Completion times range from six to fifteen minutes, and the formation dissolves during the return to Ostia. No injuries occur, but the exercise exposes the fleet's unpreparedness for real emergencies.

Juan debriefs his fleet captains after the storm readiness exercise, confirming that only Pascual knew the signal timing. Each captain honestly reports their ship's performance and failures, from the San Marcos's six-minute success to the San Vicente's fifteen-minute disaster due to hungover crew. Juan decides to grant shore leave for rest and improvement before the next drill.

After the fleet exercise debrief, Juan rewards all ships with drinks and establishes a tradition of giving wine to the best-performing vessel. He authorizes the captains to conduct another drill while he's in Rome, delegating command to Morales and encouraging them to devise new signaling methods for future training.

Juan returns to Rome from inspecting his fleet at Ostia and reunites with Lucia at the Palazzo di San Marco. She has waited up for him with food, and they share an intimate evening as he tells her about his day with the naval captains. Lucia offers wise counsel about his leadership and warns him that tomorrow's papal audience will require different skills than commanding ships.

Juan prepares for his papal audience, dressing as a Christian king rather than penitent. He meets Pope Eugenius IV in private chambers with Cardinal Capranica present. Juan kneels and diplomatically inquires about the Pope's wellbeing before offering his service to the Church.

Juan kneels before Pope Eugenius asking how he might serve the Church after visiting Basel. The Pope shows cautious interest, acknowledging Juan's credentials but questioning his middle path strategy between papal and conciliar authority, ultimately challenging whether such a position is sustainable.

Juan proposes a sophisticated strategy to Pope Eugenius for resolving the Basel crisis through parallel legislation and strategic enforcement. While acknowledging that Basel moved faster than expected, Juan outlines a two-part plan: first, Rome should adopt and actively enforce Basel's uncontroversial reforms to demonstrate papal authority in implementation; second, Rome should initiate new reforms that Basel must then follow, gradually diminishing the Council's relevance through strategic maneuvering and Italian delegate participation.

Juan proposes a sophisticated strategy to outmaneuver Basel: sign agreed reforms immediately, enforce them aggressively to demonstrate papal authority, then issue papal decrees forcing Basel to follow. Pope Eugenius responds with deep suspicion, demanding to know Juan's true price and comparing him to the Emperor's failed mediation at Como.

Confronted about his true motives, Juan delivers an impassioned declaration of pure faith, speaking of church bells and farmers at Mass. The Pope initially remains skeptical, but after rolling 93 on the response table, experiences a profound emotional breakthrough. He dismisses all attendees, confesses he has been losing faith in the Church itself, and opens himself completely to Juan as one Christian to another, offering whatever aid is in his power.

In an emotional breakthrough, Pope Eugenius reveals his crisis of faith and admits the Vatican's financial corruption. He confesses that the papal treasury is mismanaged by an opaque bureaucracy, cardinals live in luxury, and Juan's crusade funds may have been diverted. Juan proposes joint reform of the Camera, offering to help 'bring down the hammer' on Vatican corruption and forge a renewed Church.

Juan proposes joint reform of the papal Camera to address massive financial corruption. After initial fear, Pope Eugenius finds resolve through scriptural reflection, acknowledging that corrupt cardinals—not Basel—are the true enemy of the Church. He agrees to immediate action with Castilian backing, transforming from defensive survivor to reforming Pope ready to 'bring down the hammer' on corruption.

Juan and Pope Eugenius assess Vatican security vulnerabilities before launching financial reforms. The Pope reveals his precarious position—uncertain loyalties among household staff, Camera officials, and secretaries who may be compromised by Roman families. They strategize about securing documents and treasury, with Juan offering his knights to take oaths directly to the Pope for legitimacy in securing the Camera offices.

Juan and Pope Eugenius discuss the strategic details of their reform plan: securing the Camera with Juan's knights sworn to papal service, issuing reforms by motu proprio, seeking support from Christian monarchs, and replacing Castilian knights with loyal Italian soldiers. The Pope reveals the cardinals' factions—only 3-4 allies among 24, with Roman families and French cardinals as primary opponents. Juan argues that corruption, not revenue shortfalls, is the real financial problem, proposing to use his 50,000 florins to consolidate papal power.

Juan confronts Pope Eugenius about the real financial crisis—not insufficient annates but corrupt allocation by parasitic cardinals. The Pope admits his ignorance about true papal costs and agrees to immediate action: drafting a Camera audit decree, securing offices with Juan's knights, making public announcements, and writing to Christian monarchs for support.

Juan and Pope Eugenius discuss potential allies for their reform initiative, evaluating the trustworthiness of various cardinals and clergy. They decide to summon Tommaso Parentucelli, a scholar-secretary known for his integrity and frustration with Church corruption, choosing transparency over caution in their approach to building their reform coalition.

Juan and Pope Eugenius discuss their reform strategy before Parentucelli's arrival. The Pope confesses that an honest audit of the Camera would reveal extensive corruption, possibly implicating him through negligence. Juan advocates for a merciful approach—a fresh start without investigating past corruption, even accepting the loss of his crusade treasury for the greater good of church unity. They summon Parentucelli to join their reform alliance.

Pope Eugenius IV summons Tommaso Parentucelli to a private audience with Juan II and demands complete honesty about Church corruption. Parentucelli courageously confirms the accusations are largely true, describing systemic irregularities in the Camera. Juan II then announces sweeping reforms: nullifying Camera obligations, restructuring annates, and redistributing financial responsibilities between the Camera and College of Cardinals.

Tommaso Parentucelli, after criticizing the Church's endless delays on reform, is presented with Pope Eugenius's radical plan to restructure the Camera Apostolica. While recognizing the political elegance of the proposal, Parentucelli questions Juan's motives and expresses deep concern about his own safety if he helps draft such reforms, having no protection beyond his ecclesiastical position. Juan pledges his knights' protection to papal servants who aid in reform.

Juan pledges protection to Tommaso Parentucelli, offering him leadership of Camera reform with knightly support. Parentucelli demands formal papal authority and a proper title to compel cooperation from resistant clerks and cardinals. The discussion centers on practical implementation of reform rather than idealistic promises.

Pope Eugenius creates the title of Commissarius Extraordinarius for Tommaso, granting authority to examine accounts and suspend officials pending papal review. The discussion reveals the Pope's uncertainty about his nephew Cardinal Condulmer, the current Camerlengo, and whether involving him in the reform effort would bring an ally or warn their enemies.

Parentucelli reveals Cardinal Condulmer is likely an unwitting figurehead, signing documents without understanding the Camera's corrupt operations beneath him. Juan proposes an elegant solution: reorganize the Camera with clean accounting while transferring all corrupt dealings to the College of Cardinals, allowing the Camerlengo to save face.

Juan proposes a pragmatic reform strategy: create a clean papal Camera with transparent expenses while shifting all corruption and backdoor deals to the College of Cardinals. Parentucelli reluctantly agrees to implement this approach, though he struggles with letting corrupt officials escape justice. The plan would reorganize Church finances without direct confrontation, making the cardinals responsible for their own corrupt legacy.

Parentucelli agrees to reform but refuses to call it justice, explaining the complex layered records system that conceals corruption in the Camera. As plans emerge for securing evidence before it can be destroyed, Pope Eugenius raises concerns about the political implications of Castilian forces occupying papal offices, fearing it would give ammunition to his enemies at Basel.

Juan and the Pope discuss the military challenges of securing the Camera documents. The Pope reveals his limited forces: 200 papal guards of questionable loyalty, while the Colonna and Orsini families maintain their own armed men in Rome. Parentucelli demands formal written appointment before proceeding, and the Pope suggests they pause for food and reflection.

Parentucelli requests a formal commission with papal seal before recruiting allies within the Camera, arguing that men need protection before declaring themselves. Juan proposes a public spectacle of reform declarations, but both Parentucelli and Eugenius raise concerns about enemy response and long-term security after Juan's eventual departure. Juan commits to staying in Rome until the Vatican is secure.

Juan makes a solemn commitment to stay in Rome and secure the Vatican before continuing to Constantinople, even if it means delaying the crusade. Pope Eugenius tests this promise by highlighting the personal and political costs, but Juan reaffirms his dedication. The Pope, moved but cautious, calls for prayer and contemplation before they proceed with their plans.

In the Vatican's private chapel, Juan calms Parentucelli's urgency about the commission letter, insisting they pray and break bread first. After sharing a meal and Juan leading a humble prayer, the three men find quiet resolve to proceed with their dangerous plans, their fears settled though not eliminated.

After prayer in the small Vatican chapel, the three men emerge with quiet resolve. The prayer has calmed their earlier anxieties and they are ready to begin the delicate work of drafting reform documents, starting with Parentucelli's commission.

Pope Eugenius formally creates Tommaso Parentucelli as Commissarius Extraordinarius for reforming the Papal Camera, granting him sweeping investigative powers. The commission is signed and sealed with the Fisherman's Ring. Juan then kneels and pledges his protection of the Pope and all who support the reforms.

Juan kneels before Pope Eugenius and formally pledges the protection of his person and the full resources of Castile for Church reform, disclaiming any desire for reward or influence. The Pope, maintaining his dignity while clearly moved, accepts the pledge with gravity and speaks of mutual obligation, raising Juan with genuine warmth tempered by papal reserve.

Pope Eugenius responds to Juan's pledge with carefully controlled dignity, reframing the offer from protection to alliance between equals. While moved by Juan's sincerity, the Pope maintains papal authority and warns that trust must be earned through future actions.

Juan proposes parallel legislation to allow the Pope to sign Basel's reform decrees while asserting independent papal authority. Parentucelli explains the legal framework, showing how identical operative content can have different preambles without creating conflicting laws. They agree to draft a papal declaration to accompany the signature, framing the reforms as papal initiative rather than submission to conciliar authority.

Pope Eugenius IV signs an apostolic declaration asserting independent papal authority over church reforms. The carefully crafted document adopts the Basel reform decrees on pluralism, concubinage, and annates while explicitly rejecting Basel's authority to command papal action. The declaration presents the Pope as acting from his own initiative and ancient tradition rather than council mandate.

Parentucelli provides detailed analysis of Camera Apostolica's financial obligations, revealing systemic corruption including 60,000+ florins in debt to Italian banks, illegal cardinal borrowing against Church revenues, and embedded banking influence. Juan commits to honoring debts using Castilian treasury and orders comprehensive audit.

Parentucelli provides a comprehensive analysis of Church finances, detailing how papal revenues total only 100-150,000 florins annually from various fees and taxes, while the vast majority of Church wealth stays at local levels. He warns that recent reforms will further reduce papal income while expenses remain constant.

Parentucelli provides a comprehensive breakdown of Camera expenses totaling 116,000 florins annually against revenues of only 100,000 florins. Major expense categories include papal household (20,000), cardinal subsidies (25,000), military costs (10,000+), and debt service (6,000). Juan proposes reforming cardinal expenses and questions whether the Basel decree's separation of Camera and College of Cardinals might redistribute some costs.

Parentucelli provides a detailed breakdown of Camera expenses (116,000 florins annually vs 100,000 in revenue) and proposes restructuring papal finances by using the Basel decree to force the College of Cardinals to fund itself from their share of annates, reducing Camera expenses to essential papal functions of around 70,000 florins.

Parentucelli presents his economic reform proposal that would shift expenses from the papal Camera to the College of Cardinals while reducing overall spending. He argues this fulfills Basel's reform spirit better than the Council intended, forcing cardinals to economize while making the papacy leaner and more apostolic. Juan questions whether reduced revenues would impair ecclesiastical functions.

Juan raises concerns about whether reducing church revenues will harm poor bishops and cardinals. Parentucelli proposes a nuanced reform system that protects clergy with modest means while cutting subsidies to wealthy prelates through needs-based distribution and transparent accounting. Juan expresses satisfaction but wonders about adding corruption investigations to the reforms.

Juan, Eugenius, and Parentucelli debate whether to include corruption investigations in their church reforms. Despite Parentucelli's desire for justice after twenty years of witnessing abuse, they agree to focus solely on structural reform rather than punishment, offering corrupt officials a path to redemption rather than creating enemies through fear of prosecution.

Juan advocates for pragmatic amnesty over prosecution in Church reform, arguing for transforming potential enemies into allies. Parentucelli struggles with abandoning his desire for justice but ultimately accepts Juan's strategic wisdom. They craft language for an amnesty that acknowledges wrongdoing without prosecuting past corruption, while preserving the option to pursue future violations. The Pope embraces this reconciliation approach as both Gospel-centered and politically wise.

Tommaso Parentucelli undergoes a profound emotional transformation, shifting from burning fury to controlled purpose. He reveals his deep personal pain from years of witnessing corruption while feeling powerless, and finds hope in Juan's promise of future justice. The Pope and Juan acknowledge his pain and offer him a meaningful role in reform, leading to a new bond of trust and shared purpose between all three men.

Parentucelli systematically outlines comprehensive reform mechanisms for the Camera's operations, covering personnel review, banking relationships, transparency requirements, collection systems, document retention, and penalties for future violations. He then catalogs additional forms of Church corruption including simony, expectancies, coadjutors, pensions, and compositions. Juan affirms Castile's financial support and emphasizes that ending compositions will signal the Church's new direction.

Juan praises the Pope's reform decree as historic, prompting Eugenius to reflect emotionally on his pontificate's struggles and failures. The Pope expresses profound gratitude to Juan and Parentucelli for helping him rediscover his courage and purpose, acknowledging this moment as transformative communion between three men deciding to stop being afraid. They prepare to draft the final reform decree.

Working late into the night, Parentucelli drafts the comprehensive Bull of Reform—twenty articles covering papal financial reform from Camera separation to amnesty provisions. After hours of careful composition, Pope Eugenius signs the document, officially enacting the most comprehensive reform of papal finance in Church history.

After sealing the papal documents for reform, Juan, Eugenius, and Parentucelli finalize plans for tomorrow's public announcement. They arrange for Castilian soldiers to secure the Camera, with Parentucelli taking charge of protecting the records and treasury. Juan returns late at night to the Palazzo di San Marco, where Lucia waits, noting the change in her husband after this historic day of church reform planning.
