Juan II and Chrysoloras finalize the Constitution of Contributions and Claims, a comprehensive legal framework that bases territorial grants on military contribution rather than ancient bloodlines alone. The law establishes precise formulas for calculating claim strength, declares Latin Empire grants void, and creates a merit-based system for earning titles through service.

Juan visits Emperor John VIII in his private study for a farewell meeting before sailing for Rhodes. The Emperor has signed the Constitution of Contributions and Claims, and reflects on how Juan restored his ability to truly rule. They part as friends, with the Emperor promising to hold Constantinople until Juan returns.

The convoy of four carracks makes an uneventful six-day voyage from Constantinople to Rhodes with adequate winds and calm seas. Lucia rests well despite her pregnancy, soldiers maintain discipline, and the fleet arrives on schedule. Juan is welcomed personally by Grand Master Jean de Lastic and immediately announces his new title and the opening of Constantinople to Latin settlers.
events.location: Sea of Marmara to Rhodes, Maritime Voyage

events.summary: Grand Master Jean de Lastic welcomes Juan enthusiastically, revealing his long frustration with European princes who promise crusading aid but never deliver. He offers comprehensive military cooperation: 50 knights and 100 sergeants for Constantinople's defense, 2 war galleys for patrol duties, full intelligence sharing, and naval coordination. In return, he asks for recognition of the Order's sovereignty, a voice in strategic councils, and fair resolution of Hospitaller property claims in Constantinople under Juan's Constitution of Contributions.
events.location: Rhodes, Palace of the Grand Master

events.summary: Juan successfully negotiates a formal alliance with the Knights Hospitaller. Grand Master Jean de Lastic agrees to station 150 men and two galleys permanently in Constantinople, abandoning historical property claims in exchange for 2000 florins to purchase new properties. The Order will participate fully in the defense while maintaining internal sovereignty, earning titles through the contribution system.
events.location: Rhodes, Palace of the Grand Master

events.summary: Racing against a major storm while crossing from Rhodes to Naples, Juan orders the fleet to shelter at Kythera. The storm veers southward at the last moment, sparing the ships. After twelve days of smooth sailing, the convoy arrives safely in Naples where Alfonso awaits with urgent news about the ongoing war.

Sultan Murad II receives Juan's diplomatic letter from Constantinople and, after careful deliberation with his advisors, decides on a cautious engagement approach. His response will acknowledge Juan's position without warmth, leave the door open for potential meetings through intermediaries, and accept the tribute arrangement while giving minimal response to the theological questions posed.

Juan arrives in Naples to find Alfonso has successfully withstood René's siege for over two months. A major French assault six weeks earlier was repulsed with heavy casualties. René now holds the countryside but cannot break the city's defenses, while Alfonso controls the harbor and receives supplies by sea. René has offered a one-year truce, but Juan rejects any negotiation short of complete surrender and orders immediate deployment of the Castilian relief army from Palermo.

Juan decisively rejects René's truce offer, ordering immediate deployment of the assembled Castilian army from Palermo to Naples. Alfonso agrees to the aggressive strategy and arranges comfortable accommodations for the pregnant Queen Lucia at Palazzo Caracciolo. Juan begins to discuss the succession concerns of his Byzantine role as Defensor Romaniae.

Juan reveals he promised the Byzantines that Alfonso would serve as regent of Castile and inherit the title of Defensor Romaniae if Juan dies. Alfonso is deeply moved by Juan's trust, kneels before him, and swears a sacred oath binding himself and Aragon to this holy obligation, transforming their political alliance into a brotherhood united by divine purpose.

Juan introduces Alfonso to Lucia and Catalina, who are settled into the luxurious Palazzo Caracciolo. Lucia impresses Alfonso with her transformation from shy bride to formidable queen, while Catalina charms her uncle. Alfonso assigns fifty guards to protect them and promises royal treatment. In a private moment, Lucia asks Juan how long he'll be gone and shares the movement of their unborn child.

Over two weeks, Juan's army of 15,000 men successfully crosses from Palermo to Naples while cavalry probing operations dominate the countryside around Aversa. French forces are revealed to be weakened by disease and desertion, reduced to roughly 6,500-7,000 men. Captured dispatches show René's desperate situation. Meanwhile, Lucia's pregnancy progresses well and the household settles into Palazzo Caracciolo.

Juan decides on a concentrated night march strategy to trap René of Anjou at Aversa. Rather than dividing forces, the plan deploys the main army across René's northern escape route, making any retreat a costly fighting withdrawal. The commanders agree to take one day for proper preparation, with Don Fadrique scouting the route and ensuring the troops are well-fed for the march and potential battle.

The Castilian army of 19,000 men executes a night march from Naples to Aversa with excellent results. Despite the inherent difficulties of moving such a force through darkness, Don Fadrique's careful preparation and scouting pays off. The army arrives at first light in good order, deploying north of Aversa to cut off French retreat routes, with morale high and supplies arriving on schedule.

A French detection roll determined that René spotted the Castilian deployment early enough to organize a cavalry breakout attempt. With only one hour of warning, René chose to sortie with his heavy cavalry to punch through the northern road before Juan's lines could fully solidify, leading to an immediate tactical crisis as the French cavalry formed up for a charge against the still-deploying Castilian vanguard.

Juan sounds the assembly and races to reinforce the northern road with his cavalry. Rolling for the timing and strength of his arrival, he manages to gather nearly 1,200 horsemen and reaches the position with time to prepare, arriving before the French charge begins and giving his forces a strong defensive posture.

Faced with Juan's tactical positioning and arriving reinforcements, René makes a desperate calculation that his window of opportunity is closing. He orders his 800 heavy cavalry into a full charge against the Castilian lines, launching what may be his final gamble to break out of the trap at Aversa.

Juan executes a tactical masterpiece, withdrawing to his cavalry as 800 French knights charge his infantry. A devastating crossbow volley breaks the charge's momentum, the infantry holds behind stone walls, and a perfectly-timed counter-charge from both flanks destroys the French cavalry as an organized force. With 300-400 French dead and 200+ captured, Juan calls for René's surrender as the remaining French infantry stands leaderless on the field.

Juan demands French surrender with generous terms, threatening siege if refused. After brief deliberation, René of Anjou accepts unconditionally with gratitude, surrendering his sword personally while his entire army lays down arms in emotional relief, ending the war with honor preserved on both sides.

Queen Joanna II holds a triumphant ceremony at Castel Capuano, formally naming Alfonso as her heir and transferring symbols of royal authority. She praises Juan as Naples' liberator, and the Calabrian barons pledge fealty to Alfonso. René witnesses the legal extinction of his claim with dignity. The succession is secured through ceremony rather than mere conquest.

With Naples secured after René of Anjou's surrender and Alfonso V confirmed as heir, Juan finds himself in a brief calm between crises. As the Sultan's reply regarding a potential meeting is expected to arrive, Juan seeks out Alfonso to discuss their current strategic situation.

Juan proposes formally binding Castile, Aragón, and Naples under the Defensor arrangements with unified military command against the Ottomans. Alfonso accepts the principle but negotiates for partnership rather than subordination, preferring coordination and joint councils over unified command.

Juan proposes unified command for the Defensor arrangements, but Alfonso diplomatically declines formal subordination while accepting partnership. They agree on naval coordination for future Ottoman conflicts and Alfonso's gradual integration into the Defensor alliance as equals rather than hierarchy.

Juan outlines his long-term strategy to Alfonso: build strength in Constantinople for five years, then launch a coordinated campaign through Hungary to retake the Anastasian Wall from the Ottomans. Alfonso pledges full support, offering ports, provisions, and his personal participation when the time comes. They agree to formalize a treaty of alliance and mutual support for the coming crusade against Ottoman expansion.

Juan and Alfonso negotiate the final terms of their military alliance treaty, addressing concerns about obligation triggers and contribution levels. They agree on language that commits both kingdoms to anti-Ottoman operations while preserving Alfonso's sovereignty over his military decisions.

Juan visits Lucia at the Palazzo Caracciolo to discuss their future plans. They decide to remain in Naples until after the birth of their child, with Juan promising to stay and disband his army. They have an intimate conversation about Catalina's acceptance of Lucia as her mother and their hopes for creating a unified family despite the complicated legacy of Juan's first wife Isabel.

Juan disbands the Castilian army in Naples, sending fifteen thousand men home to Castile while keeping his 200 Military Order guards. He remains in Naples to await Lucia's delivery. Three weeks later, Ottoman diplomat Hamza Bey arrives bearing a message from Sultan Murad II, requesting audience with the King of Castile.

Hamza Bey, the Ottoman envoy Juan previously expelled from Constantinople, arrives in Naples bearing Sultan Murad II's response. Through careful diplomatic exchanges, they negotiate terms for a future meeting on the neutral island of Tenedos, with both rulers expressing mutual respect and wariness. Juan's honest admission of wanting to know his potential adversary personally impresses the Ottoman diplomat, who reports that the Sultan finds Juan 'dangerous' but worthy of meeting.

Juan convenes a council to plan recruitment for Constantinople settlers. His advisors debate strategy: Bernat emphasizes addressing fears about Ottoman threats, Lucia insists on appealing to women and families, Martín suggests using church networks, and Fernán stresses the need for early success stories. Juan decides to pursue a church-based proclamation addressing both men and women, emphasizing faith, protection, and honest reporting of opportunities.

Juan finalizes strategy for settling Constantinople through Church-distributed proclamations targeting Christian families. He orders Military Orders to expand to 1,000 men and establish permanent commanderies, planning to bind them to the Apokatastasis with new charters. The settlement campaign achieves extraordinary success, with over 5,000 settlers transforming the city and establishing it as a vibrant Christian center that draws notice across Christendom.

The settlement proclamation campaign achieves extraordinary success. Over 5,000 settlers will arrive in Constantinople over the next two years, transforming the city from decline to visible growth. The Military Orders seek to relocate headquarters there, Italian city-states compete for trading rights, and the Apokatastasis becomes a symbol of Christian renewal across Europe.

During the late summer of 1434, Juan experiences a rare period of calm while awaiting Lucia's delivery in Naples. With no urgent crises demanding attention, he corresponds with officials, explores the city, and strengthens his alliance with Alfonso. The peaceful weeks prove to be an unexpected blessing.

Lucia d'Este delivers her first child after a normal but difficult labor lasting through the night. Juan waits anxiously outside the birthing chamber while she endures hours of pain. Both mother and child survive the delivery, though Lucia requires weeks of recovery.

Juan's second daughter Bianca is born to Lucia Visconti in Naples. Despite the exhaustion of childbirth, Lucia maintains her wit while showing tender vulnerability. They discuss Italian names before settling on Bianca, and Juan introduces the newborn to her sister Catalina.

Juan introduces two-year-old Catalina to her newborn half-sister Bianca. Despite initial suspicion about the small, red baby, Catalina's protective instincts emerge when Bianca grasps her finger, and she solemnly promises to teach her sister about building castles when she grows bigger.

During the journey home to Toledo, young Catalina develops a mild cough and congestion. Though not serious, Juan takes precautionary measures to keep her separated from baby Bianca and recovering Lucia by turning isolation into a playful game.

When Catalina develops a minor cough during the journey to Toledo, Juan creates a playful quarantine game where they pretend to run away from Lucia and baby Bianca. Over five days, Juan plays horse for his daughter while maintaining distance from the others, successfully preventing the illness from spreading to the infant while keeping Catalina entertained and happy.

Juan returns to Toledo and meets his son Fernando for only the second time. The fourteen-month-old boy is cautious with his father, whom he barely knows. Lucia gently introduces herself as Fernando's new caretaker, while Catalina helps bridge the gap between father and son. The reunited family gathers together in the Alcázar courtyard for the first time, forming a new bond despite their complex history of loss and separation.

Juan's new family shares their first meal together in Toledo's Alcázar. The evening is chaotic but joyful, with Italian crostata, children's chatter, and domestic warmth. Later, Lucia and Juan discuss the challenge of building a new life in the shadow of his first wife Isabel, with Lucia promising to love Isabel's children as her own while creating something new.

Juan convenes his full council to review treasury expenses from 1434. Diego de Daza presents the accounting for the Naples expedition, initially conflating different funding sources before Juan corrects him. The actual crown expenditure was 42,000 florins for the Naples campaign plus 3-4,000 florins for royal fleet operations, clarifying that other expenses were drawn from separate endowments and the Constantinople joint treasury.

King Juan II decides to drastically reduce the Granada garrison from 11,000 to just 50 soldiers stationed at the Alhambra, relying instead on feudal obligations from the new lords and Military Orders to defend the conquered territory. He also chooses not to create a Duke of Granada title, maintaining direct crown control over the wealthy province's revenues and administration.

Diego de Daza presents comprehensive progress reports on tax reforms and trade revenues. The Mediterranean commerce initiative shows growth from 5,000 to 8,000-10,000 florins, with Málaga emerging as a key port. Total crown trade revenues reach 86,000-88,000 florins annually. Military expense reductions, particularly the Granada garrison cut, save 25,000 florins, bringing recurring expenses down to 90,430 florins for 1434.

Diego de Daza presents the 1434 financial review, initially projecting a treasury of 558,000 florins. When Juan points out missing estate revenues, Diego revises the accounting to properly include crown estates as a separate category, revealing a stronger position of over 606,000 florins. Juan then inquires about launching a major infrastructure investment program.

Juan II proposes a massive 150,000 florin infrastructure investment program. Diego de Daza outlines a comprehensive strategy involving prioritized investment in ports, roads, and ships over three years with strict oversight. The discussion shifts to fleet expansion for dual trade and military purposes.

Juan proposes an ambitious naval expansion program to transport 15,000 men to Constantinople if needed. The council discusses the technical challenges of mixed fleets, comparing carracks, galleys, and galleasses. After realizing the initial scale is unrealistic, Juan allocates 200,000 florins for naval expansion and recognizes the need for an experienced admiral to lead the effort.

Juan II commits 200,000 florins to naval expansion and 40,000 florins annually for infrastructure development. The council discusses the need for foreign expertise: an admiral from Aragon to lead the naval program, and master craftsmen from abroad to establish royal workshops for large-scale production of tools and weapons, transforming Castile from an exporter of raw iron to a producer of finished goods.

Juan II establishes a comprehensive manufacturing development plan for Castile, creating a Junta de Manufacturas to oversee expansion of textile, leather, silk, salt, paper, ceramics, glass, and shipbuilding industries. The council identifies specific opportunities including Segovia textiles, Córdoba leather, Granada silk recovery, and Atlantic salted fish production. The king allocates 6,000 florins for industrial development and 5,000 florins each to military orders, while Diego de Daza presents the complete 1434 budget showing a treasury surplus of nearly 346,000 florins after expenses.
